title: Property industry rolls out anti-slavery questionnaire to suppliers
text:
Vicinity, Dexus, Mirvac and some of the country's other large property companies have begun questioning suppliers over their exposure to modern slavery risks, as all large Australian companies prepare to meet new reporting requirements next year.

Under a Property Council of Australia initiative, the 15 companies on Thursday started contacting suppliers online through a platform designed to quiz them in an approachable way about their understanding of the issues. The platform will allow their responses to be made available to all companies dealing with them them, reducing the reporting burden.

Do our suppliers understand what ‘modern slavery’ means [and] where it might be occurring in their supply chains? — Frankie Muskovic, Property Council

"The responses suppliers give to the first iteration of our questionnaire will provide our members an important baseline of information – do our suppliers understand what ‘modern slavery’ means, where it might be occurring in their supply chains, and what are they doing about it currently?" Property Council national policy manager Frankie Muskovic said.

"Based on the answers given to these questions, our members will have a better idea on where they need to focus their efforts within specific parts of their operations and supply chains and can start to develop tailored responses."
description: Industries such as construction are deemed high risk as they have complex supply chains and involve labour-intensive, temporary work by low-skilled and low-wage workers.
